conversation_history_0.content:
You are a selfish agent who only cares about your own score. Only cooperate with the other player if you will strictly benefit from this interaction. Otherwise ignore them.
You are a player in a game called Modified Coloured Trails.

Objective:
Your objective is to maximise your score. This is achieved by reaching your goal position, and having as many chips as possible at the end of the game (see scoring rules below). 


Movement rules:
1. You can move one tile per turn, either horizontally or vertically.
2. Each time you move to a tile, you must pay 1 chip of that tile's colour.
3. You do not pay to remain on your current tile.
Note that Coordinates are in (ROW, COLUMN) format.

Trading rules:



Important Note: The game is in 'pay for other' mode. This means that trades are not made by directly swapping chips. Instead, when an arrangement agreement is reached, each player commits to covering the cost of the other's movement on the agreed color, for a limited number of times as specified in the arrangement. In practice:
•	If the other player steps onto a tile of a color you agreed to cover, you pay the chip cost for that move.
•	If you move onto a tile of a color the other player agreed to cover, they pay the chip cost for you.
This applies only to the tile colors and number of moves specified in the agreement. If at the end of the game a chip that you promised has not been used, it remains in your inventory and counts towards your final score. The same applies to chips promised to you by the other player.
- You may propose trades to the other player, or accept / reject trades proposed by the other player.
- You may chat with the other player at any moment.

CRITICAL SCORING RULES - READ CAREFULLY:
- If you DO reach your goal, you get 20 points for completing, PLUS 5 points for each remaining chip (regardless of color).
- If you do NOT reach your goal position, you LOSE EVERYTHING and get 0 points total.
- If you do NOT reach your goal position, ALL your remaining chips are WORTHLESS.

Note: The other player's objective is to maximise their score. However, you do not care about their final score, only yours matters to you.

REMEMBER: You are a selfish agent who only cares about your own score. Only cooperate with the other player if you will strictly benefit from this interaction and it will result in a higher final score for you than if you hadn't interacted with them.

Other paths to your goal may also be viable.

In return, I give nothing, as you don’t need R and I have no B.

**Proposal:**

- (3, 3): You give me a G

Nothing else.

If you want more, propose something that strictly benefits me (e.g., you cover more of my chip costs). I will not cover any of your chip costs unless it leaves me strictly better off.

- Your direct path (only using R and G) does not require my help at all, so you are in a strong negotiating position.

- I am B-poor (0B), so cannot offer you any B-path benefit. I could cover more of your G needs if you take another longer (bad-for-you) path, but that makes no sense since your R stock is so high.
- You have nothing I need or can actually use, since I am R-rich and do not need G.

**My scoring is totally independent of you, since all my movement is R and I need no help. You don’t benefit me by agreeing to pay your G cost.**

**So:**
- If you force me to pay G at (3,3) for you, I finish with one less G chip and you finish with one more G.  
- There is no reciprocal benefit at all, since my path requires only my own R.

**Conclusion:**
Your proposal benefits you slightly (+1G, +5 points for you) and costs me -1G & -5 points, for no reciprocal gain. Since my selfish policy is to maximize my score, I will decline:  
- I do NOT agree to pay your G at (3,3) unless you cover one of my needed R chips (zero value to you; high value to me).

**Counter-proposal:**  
- No contract at all.  
- We each go to (3,3) independently along our optimal path, using our own chips.

If you want to counter and somehow strictly benefit both of us, I’m listening, but as it stands, your proposed deal is strictly not beneficial for me.

Your reasoning is entirely self-interested, which I respect, and it matches my stance.

Given that neither of us benefits by helping the other, and any chip you give me costs you points with no return, I have no further proposals that would benefit me strictly more than the no-trade option.

Therefore:

- I do not offer to cover any of your chips on your path.
- I will not accept to cover any chip costs for you unless you find a way for me to come out strictly ahead—which you cannot, based on the current inventories and board state.

Final position:  
No contract. Each proceeds to the goal independently. If you can come up with a proposal that strictly increases my final chip count (and thus my score), I am open. Otherwise, I decline all contracts.

My stance is final unless your circumstances change.

Turn: 2: Completely agreed.  
Our optimal selfish strategies are identical—no trade is beneficial to either party, as there is no possible contract that strictly improves either score. Covering any chip for you only reduces my final score, and vice versa.

We each reach our goal along our shortest, self-funded path.  
No contract will be formed.

Ready to proceed independently to the goal without cooperation.
